```{r}
#Use R Studio File -> Import Dataset and Copy/Paste
library(haven)
library(psych)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
```

```{r}
wide <- read_sav("tolerance_wideform.sav")

long <- read_sav("tolerance_longform.sav")
```

```{r}
# Figure in Slide 14 (Wide, Long)
ggplot(long, aes(x=as.factor(age), y=TOL)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(x="age", y="Tolerance to deviance")



# Assuming your data is in a variable called 'data'
data_long <- pivot_longer(wide, cols = starts_with("tol"), 
                          names_to = "wavies", values_to = "Value")

ggplot(data_long, aes(x = wavies, y = Value)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "", y = "") # Modify axis labels as needed
```


```{r}
#  Left table in Slide 16 (Wide, Long)
describe(wide)
describe(long)
```

```{r}
# Right table in Slide 16 (Wide only)
names(wide)
wide_cor <- wide |> 
  select(2:6)
cor(wide_cor, method = "pearson")
```

```{r}
#Figure in Slide 17 (Wide, Long)
str(wide)

# Assuming your data is stored in a variable named 'data'
# Convert the 'male' column to a factor with labels for plotting
wide$male <- factor(wide$male, labels = c("Female", "Male"))

# Reshape the data to long format
data_long <- wide  |> 
  select(-id, -exposure)  |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("tol"), names_to = "Treatment", values_to = "Value")

# Create the boxplot
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = male, y = Value, fill = Treatment)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "MALE", y = "", fill = "") # Modify labels as needed

######################


```
